sense.name: the act of striking an object, usually with an implement
sense.examples: They received three strokes of the cane as punishment. At the stroke of twelve Cinderella's coach turned into a pumpkin. (clock's hammer strikes gong) A stroke of lightning split the tree trunk down the middle. He lopped the prisoner's head off with one stroke of his sword.

sense.name: a stylistic or technical manner of hitting a ball
sense.commentary: STROKE[+event][+physical][+striking][+stylistic][+of_ball] Note: a narrower, sports usage of Sense 1
sense.examples: Mary's instructor is helping her to improve her golf stroke. (how she hits the ball) That tennis player is famous for his powerful stroke. With a mighty stroke of the bat, the hitter sent the baseball out of the ball park for a home run.

sense.name: apoplexy, sudden physical disablement from the occlusion of a blood vessel to the brain
sense.examples: Rapid treatment has a significant impact on the recovery of patients who have suffered a stroke. The woman lost use of her right arm after her stroke.

sense.name: cycle of movement of a piston
sense.examples: This type of engine has four strokes, and that one only two strokes. During the power stroke of the engine, the piston is compressed.

sense.name: petting, brushing motion of the hand, or implement
sense.examples: The cat purred in my lap and seemed to enjoy the stroke of its fur. The woman gives her hair 100 strokes a day with a brush, to keep it lustrous.

sense.name: the unit of scoring in a golf game
sense.commentary: STROKE[+quantity][+unit][+scoring][+golf] Note: derived from Sense 2, but here refers to points accrued in golf, occurs with a number
sense.examples: John is currently ahead by two strokes. I was two over par on that hole because it took me five strokes to sink the ball.

sense.name: oarsman in a rowing shell who sets the pace
sense.examples: The stroke told his crew to pick up the pace as they approached the boathouse. Bob was a stroke in college for an eight. (rowing shell with 8 rowers)

sense.name: a sudden, unexpected event
sense.examples: By a stroke of good luck, I found my earring in the parking lot, after the snow melted. John's solution to our problem was a stroke of genius. The company managed to survive through several strokes of bad luck.

sense.name: a punctuation mark that functions as a separator
sense.examples: You can use either dashes or strokes as formatting punctuation for calendar dates. I wrote a stroke between the 'and' and the 'or'.

sense.name: brushed marks on a surface, using an implement
sense.examples: Analysis of the painting has concluded that the brush strokes are not those of Van Gogh. Her technique involves large sweeping strokes of bright acrylic paints on a white background. With the stroke of the President's pen, the bill became law. To make this Chinese character, first make the vertical stroke, then the diagonal ones.

sense.name: repetitive propelling beat of the body through water
sense.examples: The swimmers are practicing their strokes in the pool. John is going to teach me the butterfly stroke. He swam across the lake with a smooth, even stroke. The strokes of the rowing crew were not quite in synch with each other.

sense.name: all at once
sense.examples: She spent all her savings at a stroke.

sense.name: do not work at all
sense.commentary: IDIOM: not_do_a_stroke_of_work Note: always in the negative
sense.examples: John's brother never does a stroke of work around the house.
